title: World Tutu Day marked by ballet dancers of all ages at Hobart Town Hall - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
text:
Hobart's ballet faithful have filled the old ballroom in Hobart's Town Hall as part of World Tutu Day to celebrate of the classical dance form. 
Dancers of all ages, most wearing tutus of varied extravagance, took part in a short class. 
Tasmanian Youth Ballet Company artistic director Shayne Davies said the event was about celebrating ballet education. 
"I think it's very important," she said. 
"Children come together, they see that there's so many other people from different schools, from all around, little, young, old, that want to celebrate ballet. 
"It's about bringing the world together through social media." 
Ms Davies urged the crowd in the Town Hall to take photos and videos and to share them on social media to show how popular the older forms of dance still are. 
She said ballet was extremely popular in Tasmania. 
"At our school alone we have 150 ballet dancers, and 180 baby ballet dancers coming through," she said. 
"It's such a worthwhile thing for people to get involved in. 
"We are getting into an era where we have 18-month babies getting into ballet. 
"It's growing [in popularity] as people can access it more and afford it." 
She said ballet was a competitive industry and would build resilience in dancers. 
"It's about dedication every day and dealing with adversity, because sometimes you go into a studio and it doesn't work at all, it's about getting through that," she said. 
Dancer Molly Everett-Matthews, 14, said she had been dancing since she was six. 
"I love to perform, it's just amazing the feeling being on stage wearing your tutu and your tiara," she said. 
"You feel like a princess." Photo: Tutus and tiaras were brought out in force in the Hobart Town Hall. (ABC Radio Hobart: Carol R채채bus) 
Though the majority of dancers in the Hobart Town Hall were female, there was proof that dancing was not just for girls. 
Campbell Braithwaite was the only male dancer at the event and said he was pursuing a career in music theatre. 
"World Tutu Day is a global event to promote ballet training and education, which is really important," he said. 
"I think now there is a lot more opportunities for guys to dance, which is really promising to see. It's influencing more males to build a career out of it. 
"There's definitely a lot more guys coming into dance which is great to see."
